utterances: Well, Alex, yes and no. Everyone is worn out, and no, they're not taking a couple of days rest.
They'll get at most one day's rest.
Both Senator McCain and former Governor Romney are due to address tomorrow the Conservative Political Action Committee.
And that's going to be a major showdown, because Mitt Romney has really pitched his campaign directly at the conservative heart of the GOP.
And McCain, who has a lot of skeptics in the far right of the party, will try to reassure them that he can also be their standard bearer.
And Don, you're out there with Senator Obama.
What's going on with him?
Is he taking a break?
No. He is...
And neither are you.
We're perhaps scaling back from 20 hour days to 18 hour days, or maybe 16 hour days if we're lucky.
The Senator already held a press conference in Chicago this morning.
He declares himself the winner yesterday, but still the underdog, interestingly.
Hillary Clinton is still declaring - or is declaring herself the underdog, saying they did really well yesterday against the establishment campaign of Barack Obama.
So that's the back and forth that's going on.
Senator Obama is going to be back in Washington for a vote in the Senate on the economic stimulus package.
Then it's off to New Orleans and to Nebraska and to Seattle, where the next three contests are.
Hillary Clinton will be sending surrogates out there, people to campaign in her stead.
She will be focusing on those important contests next week, Virginia and in Washington D.C.
and Maryland.

Scott, back to you, and a question here about Governor Huckabee, who did so well in southern and border states yesterday - I think unexpectedly well - he'd been seen as sort of friendly with Senator McCain's campaign.
I think - I wonder how feelings look today there.
The McCain camp is still heaping praise on Mike Huckabee.
They have said they have a very cordial relationship.
They have strong differences on some of the issues.
For example, Mike Huckabee's support of a fair tax or flat tax, John McCain is not in favor of that.
But their debate has been very issue oriented.
They seem to have a very warm person relationship.
So they're not, I don't think, terribly troubled.
They would've liked to have won Georgia and won Tennessee, two states where they campaigned over the weekend and two states that instead former Governor Huckabee carried.
But the John McCain camp, I think, is still more worried about Mitt Romney and they see Mike Huckabee as taking more support from Mitt Romney than he is from them.
Well, you kind of wonder where things are going to go.
Don, the race ahead with the Democrats, you say they're going to Washington and then Senator Obama's headed to New Orleans, Senator Clinton elsewhere.
What are they looking at immediately for next week?
Well, you know what they're doing?
They're starting to focus on that question of electability.
And Hillary Clinton said today that Barack Obama could be swift boated.
People don't know about him yet.
Things could come up during the campaign that could knock him off guard and hurt his candidacy.
Obama responds there's a whole dump truck full of stuff that can be backed up as it relates to Hillary Clinton.
And he says Republicans will use that.
So that's the back and forth.
Okay.
It goes on.
NPR's Don Gonyea and Scott Horsley.
Thank you both.
Yeah, those kind of - now, they were already eating at the Chinese restaurants beforehand, but this really started something.
It helped start a craze, if you will, a fad, a fad that lasted quite some time.

But it really allowed the Chinese to move, to open up new restaurants, to carry that fad with them, and because people knew about it, you know, to succeed where they opened those restaurants, kind of move across the country.
Now, I want to know about those strange-looking tongs.
What are those?
Right.
The other thing that happened around that same time as the chop suey craze was starting is the introduction of the fortune cookie, the Chinese restaurant fortune cookie that we all know today.
Now, this one, I like to say, is an American invention, and the tongs were from San Francisco, and they were used to help make the first fortune cookies.
And they were called (unintelligible).
So were they cooked by the cast iron tongs?
Yeah, they would be heated up.

It's an important part of the story, and, you know, that it started, you know, so early and has become such a large part of the Chinese restaurant experience and to be identified with Chinese food (unintelligible).
Do you have any idea why it happened?
No. That's still something we're looking into.
Somehow, though, Chinese food has really captured this country.
I would venture to say that it's another personal thing, that it's the new comfort food.
It's probably as American as anything else we have on our menus and our daily eating habits.
Even if you don't like Chinese food, you can pretty much name what's going to be on the menu.
We're all familiar with it, and it's become a part of our, you know, our eating habits.
But what if you're wandering around Chinatown with an appetite for something truly authentic?
Jenny 8.
Lee has this tip:
No fully American Chinese restaurant would serve jellyfish.
(Soundbite of laughter)
No jellyfish.
It's...
No jellyfish.
It's not truly Chinese.
Yeah.
Well, you know what they do here in Washington?
I guess you do know, because I'm sure you've seen this, is that the Chinese, Chinese menu is in Chinese, posted on little flags around the walls.
Yeah.
Exactly.
It is a secret code.
It is meant to keep you guys out, actually.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And, you know - and this is - but I'll tell you what you can do.
You can do - this is an interesting trick.
You just point to very expensive things...
(Soundbite of laughter)
...and take your gamble the fact that they're expensive, that they're going to be good.
Our thanks to Jenny 8.
Lee and Cedric Yeh at the National Museum of American History, where you can see the ""Sweet & Sour"" display and use our handy tips to get a good lunch in Chinatown, which is just a few blocks away.
NPR's business news starts with the financial scandal rocking India.
(Soundbite of music)
Police this morning are standing guard outside the home of one of India's most prominent business figures.
The head of one of the country's top technology companies resigned yesterday after admitting he had cooked his books to the tune of $1 billion.
It's been called one of India's biggest corporate scandals, and the fallout is being felt in the United States.
NPR's Philip Reeves reports.
Satyam Computers was supposed to be a showpiece.
It has a glittering headquarters in the Indian city of Hyderabad, befitting India's fourth-largest software company.
It has more than 50,000 employees and an impressive list of clients, many in the U.S., some Fortune 500.
Today, clients and investors are digesting the stunning news that Satyam's 54-year-old chairman, Ramalinga Raju, has for years, on a gigantic scale, been quietly inflating the figures.
Raju penned his confession in a letter in which he took sole responsibility for the fraud.
He resigned and said he was submitting himself to the full force of the law.
He tried to fix the fraud, but couldn't.
He said it had been like riding a tiger.
Not knowing how to get off without being eaten.
India has reacted with shock.
Its stock market plummeted with the news.
Satyam's share value dropped by 80 percent.
There are concerns the scandal will discourage foreign companies from outsourcing to India.
There are worries, too, that it'll generally dent foreign investor confidence at a time when, like everybody, India is trying to weather the fallout of the global economic meltdown.
Today, India's newspapers are full of angry questions about how Raju got away with his fraud for so long.
One stands out.
Why, they want to know, didn't the auditors spot anything?
Philip Reeves, NPR News.
When Russia shut off the flow of natural gas to a neighbor the other day, it raised fears of an energy crisis in Europe.
It also underlined the power that comes with Russia's natural resources.
And that, in turn, calls attention to Russia's huge gas company.
It's called Gazprom, and it plays a role in Russia's foreign policy.
So, this morning we begin a series on Gazprom, and we start on the site of the company's biggest gas fields.
They're in Yamal-Nenets, which is a remote region of Siberia.
NPR's Gregory Feifer reports.
The wind moves slowly over an endless landscape of stunted trees and snow.
Temperatures here often reach minus 60 degrees Fahrenheit.
This land may be inhospitable, but it's the source of much of Russia's new wealth.
(Soundbite of turbines pumping gas)
Carl Mountford is BP's program manager for Liberty.
He acknowledges it's a complex project with little room for error.
But he's confident it can be done cleanly.
And I'm Melissa Block.
The housing slump just keeps getting worst, and the Federal Reserve is expected to respond today by cutting key interest rates.
A new economic report out today has some good news: better than expected growth this summer in the gross domestic product.
